author: By Kim Tingley, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Rowan Niemisto and Quinton Kamara
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Bodily Indignities of the Space Life’
description: The race is on to put hotels in space and neighborhoods on the moon. Here’s some of what we know about how Earthlings fare beyond the safety of our home world.
content: As an incubator of life, Earth has a lot going for it, something we often fail to appreciate fully from within its nurturing bounds. Merely sending probes and rovers to the moon and Mars won’t do. For various reasons — adventure! apocalypse! commerce! — we insist upon taking our corporeal selves off-world too. Multiple private companies have announced plans to put hotels in space soon. NASA is aiming to 3-D-print lunar neighborhoods within a couple of decades. And while it will probably take longer than that to build and populate an outpost on Mars, preparations are being made: This summer, four NASA crew members began a 378-day stay in simulated Martian housing at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Here’s some of what we know about how Earthlings fare beyond the safety of our home world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘The O.C.’ Creators Are Right Back Where They Started From
description: With the publication of a new book about their influential teen drama, which debuted in 2003, Josh Schwartz and Stephanie Savage have learned to love “The O.C.” again.
content: “We didn’t know anything,” Josh Schwartz said. “We didn’t know the rules and we were making it up as we went along. That’s something that you learn from.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘Bzzz’ Turns Art Forms of Solo Virtuosity Into a Group Affair
description: The tap dancer Caleb Teicher and the beatboxer Chris Celiz have expanded an earlier collaboration into an evening-length work at the Joyce Theater.
content: The acclaimed tap dancer Caleb Teicher and the world-champion beatboxer Chris Celiz might seem to belong to very different tribes. But when they met a few years ago while separately performing at a conference in Miami, they got to talking about what their art forms had in common.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Storm Moves Into Northeast, Bringing Heavy Rains and High Winds
description: Parts of central Connecticut into Massachusetts and northwestern Rhode Island could get as much as seven inches of rain, forecasters said. In New York City, a travel advisory was issued.
content: A powerful storm system began to move into the Northeast on Sunday, prompting flood and wind alerts as well as travel advisories while some areas braced for power outages and up to six inches of rain, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Vegan Food, Once Tough to Find in Berlin, Is Now Flourishing
description: Meatless menus used to be an oddity in Germany’s capital. Today, Berlin is bursting with creative vegan options, including Spanish tapas, Berliner-style doughnuts and even fast food.
content: When Tran Mai Huy Thong was growing up as a vegetarian in West Germany, his peers couldn’t comprehend his choice to not eat meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: Inside the Three Days That Reframed Black Women’s Health
description: Forty years ago, Black women convened to discuss how race affected their health, inspiring remarkable changes.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Jon Hurdle
title: At Penn, Vacancies in Leadership, and Anguish on Campus
description: One day after the resignations of the university president and chairman, students and professors reflected on the continuing division at the school.
content: One day after the president of the University of Pennsylvania resigned over criticism that she did not condemn antisemitism forcefully enough, state leaders showed solidarity with Jews at a Philadelphia rally, while students and professors lamented the ongoing rift on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: What Can You Do With an Einstein?
description: Earlier this year, mathematicians discovered a unique shape. Now do-it-yourselfers have found ingenious ways to put it to use.
content: It’s been a year of endless einsteins. In March, a troupe of mathematical tilers announced that they had discovered an “aperiodic monotile,” a shape that can tile an infinite flat surface in a pattern that does not repeat — “einstein” is the geometric term of art for this entity. David Smith, a shape hobbyist in England who made the original discovery and investigated it with three collaborators possessing mathematical and computational expertise, nicknamed it “the hat.” (The hat tiling allows for reflections: the hat-shaped tile and its mirror image.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Giuliani to Go on Trial for Damages in Defamation Case
description: A federal jury will be selected to decide how much Rudolph Giuliani should pay for spreading lies about two Georgia election workers as he fought to keep Donald Trump in office.
content: There will be no good news — only shades of bad — for Rudolph W. Giuliani when he appears in court on Monday for a trial to determine how much he will have to pay two Georgia election workers he lied about after the 2020 presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Shari Redstone Is Said to Be in Talks to Sell Her Stake in Media Empire
description: Ms. Redstone waged a bitter battle for control of National Amusements, the parent company of MTV, CBS and the Paramount movie studio. Now, she’s considering a sale.
content: The media mogul Shari Redstone is in talks to sell a controlling stake in National Amusements, the parent company of the sprawling news and entertainment empire that includes the Paramount movie studio, CBS and MTV, according to three people familiar with the talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Karoun Demirjian
title: Zelensky to Visit Washington With U.S. Aid to Ukraine in Doubt
description: Officials announced that the Ukrainian president would travel to Washington on Tuesday for a last-ditch lobbying effort with President Biden and members of Congress.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will travel to Washington on Tuesday for a last-ditch lobbying effort with President Biden and members of Congress aimed at securing billions of dollars of U.S. aid, officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: That QR Code You’re About to Scan Could Be Risky, F.T.C. Warns
description: Scammers have used QR codes to steal personal information by imitating legitimate companies or sending deceptive emails and text messages, the Federal Trade Commission said.
content: QR codes, the square bar codes that can be scanned and read by smartphones, are seemingly used everywhere: to board flights, enter concerts and look at restaurant menus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds and Jamie McGee
title: Six Dead and More Than 60 Injured After Severe Weather in Tennessee
description: Storms and tornadoes left a swath of destruction that included parts of Clarksville, where three people died, and near Nashville, where three others were killed.
content: Reed Arnold was watching TV on Saturday at his home in Clarksville, Tenn., when he saw a warning on his phone. He stepped outside and filmed the swiftly moving clouds and a looming tornado. Minutes later, the twister hit his neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: In Los Angeles, the ‘Coroner to the Stars’ Has the Last Word
description: There is no medical examiner’s office in the world like the one in Los Angeles County, where investigations of sudden celebrity deaths come with the territory.
content: In most places, it is a trade of little glamour. Transporting bodies, performing autopsies — the role of a coroner’s office tends to be dismissed as a macabre necessity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Who’s a ‘Colonizer’? How an Old Word Became a New Weapon
description: In bitter debates from Israel to Africa to America, invoking a brutal history has become a powerful accusation.
content: The colonial era entered its death throes after World War II. From 1945 through the 1960s, a global order in which European powers took political control of other countries — occupying them with settlers, subjugating the local populations and exploiting the land and its inhabitants for economic gain — unraveled. Dozens of states in Asia and Africa threw off colonial overlords. Colonialism, once equated by the West with civilizing progress, became synonymous with iniquity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Bought as an N.B.A. Team, the Mavericks Are Being Sold as Much More
description: Pro sports franchises are increasingly providing much of their value as anchors for larger business enterprises, including entertainment complexes.
content: The sales of most professional sports teams are fairly predictable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Can the Holocaust Movie Be Revelatory Again? 3 Filmmakers Say Yes.
description: Tragic tellings of the Shoah are all too common. The directors of “The Zone of Interest,” “Origin” and “Occupied City” refuse to let it live in the past.
content: In the British comedy “Extras,” Kate Winslet, who appears as a version of herself, is playing as a nun in a film about the Holocaust. When commended for using her platform to bring attention to the atrocities, she replies callously, “I’m not doing it for that. I mean, I don’t think we really need another film about the Holocaust, do we?” She explains that she took the role because if you do a movie about the Holocaust, you’re “guaranteed an Oscar.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Invites University of Phoenix to the House Antisemitism Hearing
description: The satire was only slightly less awkward than the real thing, in a freewheeling episode hosted by Adam Driver. Olivia Rodrigo was the musical guest.
content: Sometimes even an up-to-the-minute comedy show like “Saturday Night Live” can’t quite stay ahead of the news cycle. Hours after it was announced that Elizabeth Magill, the president of the University of Pennsylvania, was resigning after an appearance before Congress in which she appeared to evade questions about whether students should be punished for calling for the genocide of Jews, “S.N.L.” led its broadcast with a satirical recreation of the Tuesday hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: This ‘Magic Flute’ at the Met Lacks Some Luster
description: Mozart’s opera, tailored to families in this staging, is big on spectacle and let’s-put-on-a-show verve. What shines? Kathryn Lewek as Queen of the Night.
content: The evolution of Julie Taymor’s production of “Die Zauberflöte” from long-running hit to children’s-theater show at the Metropolitan Opera is now complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Gaza War Has Buoyed Egypt’s Leader Ahead of Presidential Vote
description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt grew increasingly unpopular amid a deep economic crisis. But the war in neighboring Gaza has given him a vital role on the international stage.
content: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt woke up on Oct. 7 remarkably unpopular for someone considered a shoo-in for a third term — guaranteed by his authoritarian grip on the country to dominate elections that begin on Sunday, but badly damaged by a slow-motion economic collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In ‘Airplane Mode,’ Not All Travelers Head in the Same Direction
description: Shahnaz Habib’s “irreverent history” takes a lively and sometimes ruthless look at who gets to go where and what gets papered over in their accounts.
content: Like exercise, flossing and college, travel has long been held up as an incontrovertible good — an essential part of the modern human experience. Lately, though, there’s been some pushback from the smart set, if not the jet set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: What the University Presidents Got Right and Wrong About Antisemitic Speech
description: The proper response to censorship is not more censorship.
content: As I watched the presidents of Harvard, M.I.T. and the University of Pennsylvania struggle last week to respond to harsh congressional questioning about the prevalence of antisemitism on their campuses, I had a singular thought: Censorship helped put these presidents in their predicament, and censorship will not help them escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Amazon Suit Claims International Ring Stole Millions in Fraudulent Refunds
description: The online retailer said that a shadowy organization bribed Amazon employees to help carry out fraudulent returns of expensive electronics, luxury goods and gold.
content: Amazon has accused an international organization, including customers and several former employees, of conspiring to steal millions of dollars in online products through fraudulent refunds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By De Kai
title: Should A.I. Accelerate? Decelerate? The Answer Is Both.
description: The OpenAI debacle illustrates the way the tech world continues to squabble about the wrong things and chase misframed goals.
content: The near-implosion of OpenAI, a world leader in the burgeoning field of artificial intelligence, surfaced a conflict within the organization and the broader community about the speed with which the technology should continue, and also if slowing it down would aid in making it more safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Goldberg and Jillian Weinberger
title: My Son Has Been Held Hostage by Hamas for 65 Days and Counting
description: Rachel Goldberg’s adult son is still being held hostage by Hamas. “I have no clue how I am able to function,” she says.
content: Rachel Goldberg’s 23-year-old son, Hersh, was abducted by Hamas at a music festival in southern Israel on Oct. 7. In this interview with the Opinion editor Sarah Wildman, Ms. Goldberg reflects on the past two months of the crisis, the recent pause in fighting and the brief moments of “delicious, thankful respite” she felt as hostages returned home — even as her son remains captive. And she argues the hostage plight should be treated as a humanitarian crisis, not a political one.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 10, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 10, 2023.
content: An article on Page 1 this weekend about a group that is trying to make synthesizers more accessible misstates the surname of a member of Synth Library. She is Mónica Torres-Ortiz, not Mónica Torres.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ari L. Goldman
title: David Ellenson, 76, Who Guided a Generation of Reform Rabbis, Dies
description: A teacher and rabbi, he forged alliances across all branches of Judaism, and his scholarship confronted questions of Jewish tradition and modernity.
content: Rabbi David Ellenson, a scholar who wrestled with the interplay of tradition and modernity in Judaism and who shaped a generation of Reform rabbis as a teacher and later as the president of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Big Commotion
description: Luke K. Schreiber makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: John Whitmire, a Moderate Democrat, Wins Runoff for Houston Mayor
description: Mr. Whitmire, a state senator, prevailed over U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee to lead the nation’s fourth-largest city.
content: John Whitmire, a moderate Democrat who has served in the Texas State Senate since 1983, won a runoff election on Saturday to become mayor of Houston, according to The Associated Press, defeating Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a prominent congressional Democrat, in the nonpartisan race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: This A.I. Subculture’s Motto: Go, Go, Go
description: The eccentric pro-tech movement known as “Effective Accelerationism” wants to unshackle powerful A.I., and party along the way.
content: On a Monday night last month, a few hours after OpenAI held an event for developers in downtown San Francisco, hundreds of artificial intelligence aficionados packed into a three-story nightclub several blocks away to celebrate a looser, less corporate vision of the A.I. future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Year of the Mega Sleeve
description: Raglan, fluted, leg o’ mutton, bishop, puffed, balloon — whatever you want to call them, we wore them.
content: When Holly Waddington, the costume designer for “Poor Things,” Yorgos Lanthimos’s much heralded phantasmagorical film about a young women’s psychological and sexual awakening that opened on Friday, began thinking about what her heroine would wear, she said she was thinking “skinny arms and these kind of straight skirts with the big bustle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: A World Map With No National Borders and 1,642 Animals
description: Anton Thomas, a New Zealander in Melbourne, Australia, has given three years of his life to a hand-drawn map of our planet and its animal inhabitants.
content: A self-taught artist-cartographer and outdoorsman spent three years on an obsessive labor of love with few parallels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Ohtani’s Contract Goes Beyond Dollars and Sense
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers are betting $700 million that Shohei Ohtani can deliver championships and help increase revenue. But the economics of sports can be fickle.
content: Japanese baseball players are taught to keep a low profile and let their performances do the talking. Yet for more than a decade, Shohei Ohtani has been willing to make waves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
title: ‘Buying Quiet’: Inside the Israeli Plan That Propped Up Hamas
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gambled that a strong Hamas (but not too strong) would keep the peace and reduce pressure for a Palestinian state.
content: Just weeks before Hamas launched the deadly Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, the head of Mossad arrived in Doha, Qatar, for a meeting with Qatari officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Brad Plumer and Vivian Nereim
title: Saudi Arabia Is Trying to Block a Global Deal to End Fossil Fuels, Negotiators Say
description: The world’s leading oil exporter has become the most forceful opponent of a new agreement at the U.N. climate summit, according to people inside the talks.
content: Saudi Arabia, the world’s leading exporter of oil, has become the biggest obstacle to an agreement at the United Nations climate summit in Dubai, where countries are debating whether to call for a phaseout of fossil fuels in order to fight global warming, negotiators and other officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Monday Briefing: The U.N. and W.H.O.’s Dire Gaza Warnings
description: Plus, Shohei Ohtani’s $700 million contract
content: U.N. officials warned yesterday that pressure was mounting near Gaza’s border with Egypt, where tens of thousands of Palestinians have tried to flee Israel’s military campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Miriam Jordan and Rebecca Noble
title: To Handle a Surge of Illegal Crossings, Border Officials Stop Legal Ones.
description: Some border communities in the U.S. and Mexico are suddenly cut off from each other after a border crossing closed to cope with large numbers of migrants.
content: Like many people in the tiny town of Why, Ariz., Stephanie Fierro’s life revolves around the nearby border crossing. She works at a roadside café serving enchiladas to American tourists passing through on their way to beach resorts in Mexico. Her husband, a Mexican citizen, lives on the other side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board and Adam Riding
title: A Refugee Finds Stability After Years of Flashbacks
description: Help with housing costs eased the transition to a new home in Phoenix.
content: Twenty-three years ago, Abwe Songolo made the fateful decision to keep moving. It was August of 2000, and he had spent hours sailing across Lake Tanganyika from his hometown in the Democratic Republic of Congo to the city of Kigoma in Tanzania, where he had to live on the streets. He had escaped the war engulfing Congo, but Tanzania still felt too close to home. “I wanted to go as far as possible from Congo because of what I’d experienced,” he said. “Because I would have flashbacks of it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Rick Ahearn, Advance Man for Candidates and Presidents, Dies at 74
description: Renowned for his professionalism and attention to detail, he worked for Republicans from Nixon to Trump. He was by Ronald Reagan’s side when he was shot in 1981.
content: Though Rick Ahearn was just a few feet from John Hinckley Jr. when he opened fire on Ronald Reagan and his entourage outside the Washington Hilton on March 30, 1981, he was most likely among the last people in the city to know that the president had been shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Shlomo Avineri, Israeli Scholar Skeptical About Peace, Dies at 90
description: A former liberal government official, he saw little chance of full reconciliation with Palestinians in “the foreseeable future” but nevertheless sought to ease tensions.
content: Shlomo Avineri, an Israeli political scientist, historian and former government official whose pessimism about resolving the conflict with Palestinians did not stop him from advocating measures to ease it, died on Nov. 30 in Jerusalem. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vaughn Vreeland
title: Cookies for the Holidays
description: A behind-the-scenes guide to Cookie Week.
content: Hi, everyone! I’m Vaughn, a supervising video producer for New York Times Cooking. And today, we’re talking all about cookies. Specifically, what separates the humdrum from the ho-ho-ho, the blasé from the trailblazing, the “just fine” from the “those were the best I’ve ever had.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Met in the Morning a Few Days Later and Talked for Five Hours’
description: Morning coffee in Brooklyn, a captive audience on the subway and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Fraught Question for the Moment: Is Anti-Zionism Always Antisemitic?
description: From the halls of Congress to America’s streets and universities, a once largely academic issue has roiled national discourse, inciting accusations of bigotry and countercharges of bullying.
content: The brutal shedding of Jewish blood on Oct. 7, followed by Israel’s relentless military assault on Gaza, has brought a fraught question to the fore in a moment of surging bigotry and domestic political gamesmanship: Is anti-Zionism by definition antisemitism?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: The Theological Truth We Must Press During War
description: Ministers should encourage people to do what our faith tells us to do over and over, which is to see the humanity in everyone, even our enemies.
content: I am ordained, but I do not pastor a church. Still, I am often invited to be a guest speaker or lecturer in congregations and universities. Lately, when people ask me questions afterward, they want to know my opinion about the war between Israel and Hamas. I am happy to answer them. Members of the clergy aren’t shut off from the world, and I don’t think our words should be either — we can be a force for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: As Fury Erupts Over Campus Antisemitism, Conservatives Seize the Moment
description: Republicans have been attacking elite universities for years. After a tense congressional hearing last week, many on the left are joining them.
content: For years, conservatives have struggled to persuade American voters that the left-wing tilt of higher education is not only wrong but dangerous. Universities and their students, they’ve argued, have been increasingly clenched by suffocating ideologies — political correctness in one decade, overweening “social justice” in another, “woke-ism” most recently — that shouldn’t be dismissed as academic fads or harmless zeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Deny Trump’s Request to Freeze Election Case
description: The special counsel Jack Smith told the judge she should keep the trial’s start date in March and continue making decisions as the former president appeals one of her rulings.
content: Federal prosecutors on Sunday asked the judge handling former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election to reject his request to freeze the case in its entirety as Mr. Trump appeals her recent ruling that he is not immune from prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Sele
title: Low Prices and High Hopes at a Pop-Up Market on Randall’s Island
description: Since early October, an ecosystem of barbers, vendors and chefs has sprung up outside one of the city’s largest migrant shelters at Randall’s Island Athletic Field 83.
content: Dusk was falling on a chilly fall day on Randall’s Island and a small crowd of people from around the world were milling around New York City’s newest pop-up market. Latin music played as the day’s last shoppers bought their dinners and vendors began packing up their tables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Netanyahu and Putin Speak, and Offer Different Versions of What Was Said
description: It was the first call in weeks between the two leaders, whose relationship has been strained since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke by telephone on Sunday for the first time in weeks, offering sharply different accounts of what was said in a reflection of the strained relationship between the two leaders since the outbreak of war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: ‘I left my good friends’: In videos shown in Tel Aviv, freed hostages share their stories.
description: Some of those who spent weeks in captivity addressed the cameras for the first time.
content: Sitting on a couch next to a crocheted blanket, Adina Moshe introduced herself in a video as having been released from the captivity of Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Lear Brought a Fuller View of Black Life Into America’s Living Rooms
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 10, 2023.
content: “It’s like asking someone who played basketball if Michael Jordan influenced them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Meredith Kolodner
title: Columbia and N.Y.U. Would Lose $327 Million in Tax Breaks Under Proposal
description: Under the plan, the universities, which do not pay property taxes, would have to make payments to the City University of New York.
content: State lawmakers will unveil legislation on Tuesday that would eliminate enormous property tax breaks for Columbia University and New York University, which have expanded to become among New York City’s top 10 largest private property owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 11, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Mistral, French A.I. Start-Up, Is Valued at $2 Billion in Funding Round
description: The company has publicly released its latest technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like OpenAI and Google argue that approach can be dangerous.
content: Mistral AI, a Paris start-up founded seven months ago by researchers from Meta and Google, has raised 385 million euros, or about $415 million, in yet another sign of feverish interest in a new kind of artificial intelligence that drives online chatbots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Casey DeSantis Invited Outsiders to Caucus in Iowa. The State Party Said No.
description: The Iowa Republican Party reminded supporters that only residents can vote in the first-in-the-nation caucuses, which will be held on Jan. 15.
content: Casey DeSantis, the wife of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, drew criticism on Saturday from the rival campaign of former President Donald J. Trump for seeking to recruit out-of-state supporters to participate in the nation’s first Republican nominating contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire
title: The Guns Were Said to Be Destroyed. Instead, They Were Reborn.
description: Communities across the U.S. are fueling a secondary arms market by giving seized and surrendered guns to disposal services that destroy one part and resell the rest.
content: When Flint, Mich., announced in September that 68 assault weapons collected in a gun buyback would be incinerated, the city cited its policy of never reselling firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Fallout From the College Presidents’ Antisemitism Testimony
description: Readers respond to the college leaders’ remarks at a House hearing. Also: Homeless on the subway; Jewish women playwrights; baby names.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Fishkin and William E. Forbath
title: Want to Tax the Rich for Real? Pay Attention to This Supreme Court Case.
description: Why the court should not give favorable tax treatment to the wealthy.
content: Last week, the wealthiest Americans had their day in court. The case before the Supreme Court, Moore v. United States, is a challenge to an obscure and narrow provision of the tax code, in Donald Trump’s Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, that taxes certain assets held abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A 3-Year Odyssey in Pursuit of a Mountain Mystery in Argentina
description: A camera emerged from the ice, with possible clues about a mountain-climbing tragedy. Could a Times reporter take a look?
content: I got a message in 2020 from a photographer and climber in Argentina named Pablo Betancourt. He had read something I had written years earlier and had discovered something that he thought might make for a good story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Dr. Gao Yaojie, Who Exposed AIDS Epidemic in Rural China, Dies at 95
description: Despite government efforts to silence her, she drew global attention to an epidemic that devastated rural China and killed tens of thousands.
content: Gao Yaojie, a Chinese doctor who defied government pressure in exposing an AIDS epidemic that spread across rural China through reckless blood collection, died on Sunday at her home in Upper Manhattan. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Biden Steps Out in Tinsel Town and the Big Donors Show Up
description: The president was back on the fund-raising trail in Los Angeles this weekend after a hiatus because of the writers’ and actors’ strikes.
content: President Biden is facing multiple wars, economic anxieties, the indictment of his son and flagging poll numbers. But he was received in California this weekend like a superstar, headlining the hottest events in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: The Book World Still Isn’t Diverse. Dhonielle Clayton Is Trying to Change That.
description: Her solution? A packaging business that sells ideas for commercial genre fiction featuring characters from broadly diverse backgrounds.
content: One evening this fall, a crowd of writers and publishing professionals mingled in a speakeasy-style lounge in Midtown Manhattan. The party, hosted by a new company called Electric Postcard Entertainment, was the kind of lavish affair that’s become rare for the book business in an era of corporate consolidation and cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Will Not Testify as Scheduled in Civil Fraud Trial
description: Donald J. Trump has changed his mind about returning to the witness stand on Monday to testify in his own defense.
content: Donald J. Trump has decided not to return to the witness stand to testify on Monday as he had planned, setting up an abrupt and anticlimactic ending to the defense’s case in his civil fraud trial in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Chicken on Bread in Sauce in a Skillet
description: Elemental comfort cooking.
content: Good morning. Remember when you weren’t that good at this business of preparing food for yourself, your family, your friends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Chris Cameron
title: Days After Heated Debate, G.O.P. Candidates Take a Gentler Tone in Iowa
description: The rivals for the Republican presidential nomination — minus Donald Trump — appeared at a “faith and family” event and talked in more personal terms.
content: Casey DeSantis recounted a few humorous interactions between her husband, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, and their children. Then she spoke in more sober tones about her fight against cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Children of Jailed Narges Mohammadi Accept Her Nobel Peace Prize
description: At the ceremony in Oslo, the Iranian activist’s twins also read a speech from their mother calling for a “globalization of peace and human rights.”
content: Iran’s most prominent human rights activist, Narges Mohammadi, was supposed to be handed the Nobel Peace Prize at a ceremony in Oslo on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: David Byrne Isn’t Himself. Or Any Self, Really.
description: “It’s all about me, me, me. That’s what you think, but everything you’re saying is coming from people around you,” says the musician.
content: “It’s all about me, me, me. That’s what you think, but everything you’re saying is coming from people around you,” says the musician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Several People Dead After Tornadoes Strike Tennessee
description: The severe storms also injured dozens, caused electrical flashes and explosions, knocked out power for tens of thousands and left buildings in ruin.
content: The severe storms also injured dozens, caused electrical flashes and explosions, knocked out power for tens of thousands and left buildings in ruin.
source.name: The New York Times
